description: I attending a wedding reception here, at the Imperial Garden Seafood Restaurant, on San Bruno IN San Francisco. Man, side note, just the address got me all screwed up. Their adjacent parking lot is tiny but at least there is one. For the event, there was no parking lot attendant. So, I'm sorry I can't tell you if there is one regularly. It looked like there was some street parking but not much.  This restaurant is on a pretty busy street. The entrance to the restaurant isn't anything grand but their food sure was tasty.  The service was OK but I can't say it was the best. After all, there were more than 200+ people that they were waiting on for this reception, not including their general restaurant guests.  Because we were there for the wedding reception, the general public that came in were kept to one side of the restaurant so as not to disturb the wedding events. Once the servers kinda got into the swing of things, getting what we needed was much easier. I'd easily come her again considering everything that we had was really tasty.  We had dishes like jellyfish, bbq pork, pork belly, a whole steamed fish, honey walnut shrimp, etc.  I can't say that we had anything exotic but I'm glad that each of the dishes we had were all very nicely prepared and tasty. Again, because we were here for a wedding reception I can't comment on pricing or anything like that. Sorry I can't be of more help. Another side note, the restrooms were clean. We didn't have to send any dishes, tea cups or utensils back to be re-washed. All the linens were clean and nicely pressed. Nice.
author: Chris C.

description:
Someone got lean way of getting in early while other people waited outside for no reason
-will update later
author: Trinny T.

description: My mom was here with her friends for lunch and was surprised with maggots coming out of the ceiling, landing on her plate and her friend's head. On top of that, the restaurant still made them pay. All they did was waive their tea fee(BRUH). I don't know if anyone has reported this, but I thought that I'd at least give a heads up here. DISGUSTING! DO NOT COME HERE!
author: Benjamin W.

description:
I didn't even get to eat here. 

Let me explain: 

This past Saturday after shopping at Alemany Farmers' Market, Wifey and I decided to grab a bite to eat at her old neighborhood. We've always passed by this place over the years, but never actually eaten here. The place was always packed with diners so I assumed the food must be good. We were strollin' around San Bruno Ave. so we decided it was time to give this place a try. It was also one of the few times I didn't check the app for ratings assuming lots of diners equals good food. 

It was around noon time as we walked in the door as I approached the host/hostess stand, which was empty. I noticed a couple off to my side with a baby stroller were sitting down (Caucasian male and Asian female) who were obviously waiting with a strained look on their faces. I turned around and there was a lady by the counter and it took a while before we could communicate to reserve a table. I finally got to speak with her and told her table for two as she wrote down her name. 

Wifey sat down as I stood by the door and began to browse on my phone. There were a lot of people who came in after us and it appears they were getting seated first. I assumed they already had reservations so we just waited patiently. But the couple, especially the male, would get up and check with the host/hostess stand on every occasion as the minutes continued ticking and the same pattern occurred of people (all Asians) continued to get seated before us. Maybe they were all regulars who happened to have reservations, I thought again. Wifey also checked with lady who took our name to check the wait time and saw that there were only a few names listed on the sheet and wondered if there was a secret reservations process. 

The process repeated itself as people who came in after us (all Asians) would approach them and get seated right away. The male waiting before us also approached the host/hostess again and wondered the same as his voice began to get elevated and he was obviously perturbed at this point. We made quick eye contact with each other and were probably thinking the same thing without saying a word and understanding each other telepathically. 

Wifey said, "Let's go" and I agreed as we both extricated ourselves from the situation. 

Adios...
Vamonos....
Zaijian....
author: John G.

description:
Dim sum is on the bland side, but that's fine since bland over over-seasoned. I could do with some sauce on the side. There are no sauces on the table, so if you like sauce with your dim sum, you'll have to ask. Unfortunately, there is no sate. The server looked at me like I was an alien when asking for sauces...

Overall, I liked the dim sum as the flavor was alright and the taste was fine. the quality was also pretty good.

Restaurant is a large flat room, quite spacious. It looks old and would do well with some renovations.

Service was pretty fast. You should probably have a Cantonese speaking person in your party, though. You'll get better service. Lucky me.
author: Jasmine P.

description:
3.5 stars 

Small parking lot right next to the restaurant. If that's full, you will have to look for street parking. 

The inside looks pretty old, they have been around for at least like 20+ years I think. 

They serve dim sum in the day. Never been. Came here for dinner with my family.  I think this is a pretty decent Chinese restaurant. Very affordable. $166 for 8 dishes. Food is pretty good. I like their quail dish. Service is pretty good as well. They came over and refilled our teas and changed our plates during our meal. They even give you free dessert at the end. Overall I didn't have much complaints about this place. Not sure why the ratings are so bad.
author: Karen L.

description:
An OK dim sum place.

Located in San Bruno, this place is one of the few sit-down dim sum restaurants in the area. The inside is big, roomy, spacious and clean. The atmosphere is a bit run-down because it's been around for a while, but hey, that's how you know they have had returning customers for years :) It's quite popular.

The parking is a bit hectic. They have their own parking lot but it's always full. They literally hire a guy who stands there full-time to make sure only customers get to park there.

The food is pretty good. They have a wide selection of dim sum to choose from. Everything is served hot and are flavorful. Not too oily. They have a lot of servers that constantly walk around showing new food made fresh from the kitchen, so that's nice.

Overall, a pretty good dim sum place.
author: Henry L.

description: If you're expecting great customer service that waitstaff will be at your every beck and call, avoid this place. But if you want good dim sum, or some decent specials that the staff knows is good, go on in!
author: Nathan S.

description: The foods alright. But what really bothers me is how the front desk people clearly speak English, but when you ask them a question they play the "no speak engrish" card.
author: Raymond G.

description:
I came here awhile back, trying to find a quick lunch before heading back into South Bay. They were offering dimsum, so I was intrigued. What i didnt know was that they were expecting us to do the whole dimsum experience, with the carts and everything... when there was barely any carts roaming around. When i explained that we were in a rush, they tried to be accommodating by giving us a menu to order from.  
Aside from that fact, they were pretty rude and hovered around us while we ordered, and rushed us even more, since we could not do that whole dimsum/yumcha experience. 

The dimsum we got was okay. We got the the har gow, the dried shrimp rolls, and their specialty soup dumplings. The only thing that stood out to me was their soup dumplings that they have in a wooden platter. It looks pretty cool. It was about 20 dumplings, each in their own separate spoon, and a sliced carrot on the bottom. It was really good, the soup was still hot and the pork dumpling was juicy. Presentation was nice considering what it was.

The neighborhood is too small and cramped for a restaurant this size. It's built horizontally instead of up, so the efficiency of space is completely lacking. Parking lot is also small and doesnt equate to at least half of the number of people that could be seated in this restaurant.

One star because of their rude interactions with us, and the food was below average. I added a star because of their soup dumplings, and because they tried to accommodate us in the best way possible, and they rush ordered our food for us.
author: Vivian H.

description:
Located in a pretty gritty part of SF, Imperial Garden is a large Chinese seafood restaurant offering classic Cantonese cooking. I came here for a huge group event (my mom's birthday), at which we booked over 10 tables and enjoyed many classic dishes of a Cantonese seafood banquet. Overall, the dishes were pretty average in terms of execution, freshness, and flavor.

We started with the cold appetizer plate of cold cut beef, barbecue pork, seaweed, and jellyfish, before moving on to the seafood soup. The cornstarch laden soup was lacking in flavor and texture, but more good stuff came soon after! The walnut prawns were nice and crispy--not overloaded on the mayo, and the Mongolian beef with king trumpet mushrooms was so tender. My overall favorite dish was probably the ginger stir-fried lobster, which came with huge chunks of delicious meat! Another favorite of mine was the steamed whole fish--you could really taste the freshness of the extremely tender flesh, soaked in a light soy sauce. We also had a stir-fried luffa vegetable dish, which was a bit greasy, and the chilled chicken and scallop fried rice to finish off the meal.

I've been to my fair share of seafood banquets (especially as a kid), and while the food at Imperial Garden wasn't close to the best of what I've had, the restaurant provided an overall enjoyable experience! However, the atmosphere and service don't earn much praise--the restaurant had a somewhat unclean feel to it, and several servers ignored our requests for water.
author: David K.

description:
Food was not good. Ordered 2 vegetable dishes and 2 clay pot dishes. They were all either salty or flavorless. The only dish that tasted alright was the sautéed scallops and shrimp with snap peas. The waiter kept forgetting parts of our order. First it was the beverages, then it was the soup. We had to keep reminding them to bring our food. 
To make matters even worse, one of the clay pots had a metal shard inside of it. Seriously? The waiter didn't seem too apologetic about it, but they did end up taking it off our bill which we appreciated. 
Minus the clay pot our meal turned out to be $60+. Definitely not worth it. Do yourself a favor and avoid this restaurant.
author: Flora C.

description:
Lots of pleasant surprises 

Maybe I just don't go eat DimSum enough, but I found lots of pleasant surprises on Sunday here.  For some reason, I didn't expect to see Xiao Long Bao (小笼包) being served, given most everything was traditionally Cantonese.  The baked Char Sui Bao (叉烧包) was also very good.  Usually made with egg whites to give an outer coat just a touch of crispiness, the bases tasted like they were baked in butter.  

The Liang Ban Hai Zhe (jellyfish with seaweed - 海蜇) had a great ginger taste to it, with a touch of pepper made it spicier than usual.  Again, a pleasant surprise. 
 
Last but not least, the value.  For our table of 10, it was, gratuity included, about $20 per person.
author: Justin L.

description:
My parents live in the neighborhood and as much as we have and want to continue to support this restaurant, I just can't say it is of any good quality anymore.  At one point it was decent, but the service and quality of food have been in decline in recent years. 

We ordered a cold plate - tofu skin w bean curd.  It came out frozen inside.  Every piece anyone took from the plate was frozen in the middle.  We had ordered two plates, so we wanted to return one (the one no one touched).  The manager tried to say this was appropriate, that it was a cold plate, that this is what the dish was supposed to be like, then tried to alleviate the situation by taking the plate and heating it up and bringing it back out to us steaming hot  -  AFTER we said we did NOT want the plate anymore.  They didn't take any responsibility for this and kept it on our bill.  

Oh, did I mention that they charged tea on the bill for my nieces and nephews who are all under 10 years-old and had ice water?  Even when we asked about that, they unapologetically said, yes, we charge all children for tea too.  Wow. 

They even added Togo box and bag charge to the bill when we never even asked for any.  We did NOT intend to bring anything away from this restaurant.  

I won't be coming back and I'm not sorry.
author: Tea Lyves ..

description:
Came here on Memorial Day for dim sum with friends.  We managed to get a parking spot in the small 10 car parking lot.
Our friends were regulars, so they already have a large table.   The food came fast and was good!  We enjoyed it!
author: Jack W.

description: Fucking nasty restaurant. I will never come back again after I ate a dim sum with  shit.
author: Jessica C.

description:
5 stars for what it is. This is a nice down & dirty no nonsense dum sum spot. A great neighborhood restaurant. 
They are incredibly affordable & have tanks filled with seafood that kids love.
The restaurant has a private little free parking lot which is sometimes staffed.
They bring the dim sum items around on trays & some carts. There is also a menu for you to order additional items.
On Saturday mornings they have a perfect speed on bringing out item. (We have only been on Saturday mornings)
.
The bathroom is pretty typical for a dim sum restaurant but not disgusting.
My husband & I will return many more times & plan to make this our regular dim sum yum yum place.
author: Ashley G.

description: It's the only big Chinese restaurant in the Silver area. The quality of the food has been up and down through out the years. Mostly down in my opinion. Last month we have a big family dinner there. I was pleasantly surprised by how good the food was! Everything we ordered was good to great. The service was great too. I hope they keep it up.
author: Mike W.

description: Excellent for dim sum.  Extensive dim sum menu and consistent quality.  Always a line because of its popularity as a family or group gathering place for the delicious morsels of dim sum.  Also order from their regular food menu as well. Mix and match!
author: Esther W.

description:
The place is always filled with Chinese people.  It bodes authenticity.  If you don't speak Chinese or look Chinese, and feel adventurous, come with a good attitude and you'll have fun.  Yes everything from dumplings to chicken feet.  It's entertaining and fun.  Your fun may vary according to your mood.

If you pretend you've just traveled to China, you'll be fine.  

I had their Dim Sum which means to point to your hearts content.  Waitresses bring by trays of dishes and you point to what you want.  It's not cheap, I came here by myself for lunch and spent $20 for 3 dishes.  It was satisfying and definitely authentic!
author: Harry W.

description: I've been here on multiple occasions, however today will be my last. Waited an hour for our meal after ordering. Two tables next to us who sat down and ordered after us were half way through their meals. 2 of their dishes were the same ones we ordered. When prodded about the long wait, they just laughed it off. Believe me I won't be coming back in the future.. horrible service to say the least.
author: Karen Y.

description:
Decent food and service. Wish there's better parking around the area though, they do have a tiny parking lot but that gets occupied really fast and almost always no opening.

I've had better Chinese food elsewhere but given this is the only dim sum place in this hood, I'll probably come back for a quick dim sum fix.
author: Elaine Y.

description: I don't know why this place has such poor ratings. My family and I really like this place. First and foremost, the food is so affordable. It's also usually packed with customers for dinner. Everything we order each time is on point. Their seafood is super good too! Overall, I don't really have a complaint about this place. The workers are very kind and they even replace your plate for a clean plate in the middle of your meal. At the end of the meal, they offer free dessert too. I always choose the mango pudding.
author: Annie H.

description:
Bummer, I really wanted to like this place too.  The food was kind of good, but falls short compared to better dim sum places I've been to (please keep in mind that I've had dim sum all around the world).  The turnip cake, and rice noodle with shrimp inside are my favorite items there.

The service, however, was terrible.  We had to seat ourselves, and no one bothered to take our food order sheet.  It took some serious hunting to get my order placed, and I had to get up to get my own soy sauce and hot sauce.  

What really upset me about this place though, was how rude/clueless one of the employees was to us, when we were trying to enjoy our meal.  Apparently, there was a large group (2 big tables full) who wanted to take a group picture right where we were sitting.  In the middle of our meal, the employee then told us we had to move our table.  I was baffled, and didn't know how to respond, so the employee immediately proceeded to drag our table out of the way.  This of course, caused all the tea to spill.  Needless to say, we shortly left after that fiasco.
author: Eric L.

description:
I came to this restaurant because my friends recommended the dim sum. And so I thought the dinner would be decent too. I really should have read the reviews on Yelp before coming here. The tldr is, if you ever think about coming here, note that

1. The service is better if your party speaks Chinese (Cantonese preferred)
2. The price of the dishes are really not worth their taste

My friend and I came for dinner on an ordinary Friday night. He speaks no Chinese, and I speak some limited Mandarin. We were seated towards the back of the banquet hall.

I didn't notice how terrible our service was until my friend pointed out that we had been waiting for 40 minutes, and our two Chinese dishes still hadn't come out yet. We looked around us, and it was obvious that other parties, some who came in later than us, were getting their dishes a lot earlier than we were. Our first dish came after an hour of waiting, and our second dish came 10 minutes afterwards.

The dishes were pretty bad, especially for the wait time. We ordered some beef chow fun (wide Chinese noodles with beef) and peppered beef. The peppered beef was not worth the $15, and the chow fun noodles were bland. (There was not much beef in the noodles either.)

Overall, I'm most irritated by the fact that they were not actively serving us, and kept their attention on other people in the banquet hall. One of the waiters and the manager were hanging around one of the other tables, telling jokes and getting all chummy with them. (The waiter had his arm around one of the customers there.) Basically, if we were Cantonese speaking people who ordered more food for ourselves, the night could have gone a lot better. I had to hunt down one of the waiters to get our check, and I left with a message of how terrible their service was, giving no tip.

Also, while serving dishes to customers, the manager stuck his pinkie super deep into his nose digging for gold. That was super gross too.

Honestly, if you want good Chinese food for a decent price, there are so many other cheaper Chinese food places on San Bruno Avenue. But I definitely do not recommend this place in any way.
author: Henry L.

description:
For the price, and the fact that it is near my workplace, I like this place. Yes, you can get better dim sum but at much higher prices. So, my expectations will be higher. 

Regarding the icons:
The Phoenix talons (braised chicken feet) were spot on tender without being mushy and properly seasoned. Siew Mai were fat. HarGow had plump shrimp and thin skin. Har Cheong Fun had a Noodle that was a bit thick for my liking. Most items were good to excellent.

Yes, the wait staff were brisk and curt, but they were nowhere as rude and insulting as some other restaurants I've endured...

The raucous din from entire households in this eatery allows for some focused eating since conversation is near impossible unless you yell. And if you devour the stackable tubs as fast as they sling them to the table, you will likely beat your colleagues back to the office.

I did not see any hygiene horrors, but I am not put off by them anyway having eaten copious amounts of street food in SE Asia.
author: Lu-Shien T.

description: Har gow (pork) and siu mai (shrimp) dumplings, two very common dim sum types, somehow just didn't taste right - texture was off. There's lots of tables and room inside so even if crowded there's barely that much of a wait. It was a little overpriced for some items and flavors were either over-salted or bland.  They were short on one of the menu items I wanted on the day I visited. I only went here since I was running errands nearby and was hungry for dim sum. I don't think there's enough pull for me to return.
author: Vinh T.

description:
Unfortunately, choosing 0 stars is not an option for Yelp.    Out of desperation, and because I was already running late for my family's CNY dinner, I decided to forego my usual dependable Clement Street take out spots and order dinner from this place.   6 noodle dishes came out to be $98.  Wow.  There's nothing special about the noodle dishes, just standard dry beef chow fun, curry beef stew chow mein and scrambled egg and shrimp chow fun.  Extremely overpriced considering that this place is not Koi Palace, Dragon Beaux or HK Lounge.

The worse part was that I called in at 4:45 for my order.  The person who took my order even called back in 5 minutes to confirm that I was actually going to come in.   Lo and behold, I arrived at 5:25 expecting to have my food ready.   They gladly rang my credit card and told me that it's coming out.   20 minutes later, my noodles came out.   They started cooking as soon as I paid.

In retrospect, I should have known better than to:
1. Pay before I receive my food.  I could have left when I arrived and it wasn't ready.
2.Trust a place with 2.5 stars.

I haven't even tried the food yet and I've already got a super bitter taste in my mouth.
author: Quinn W.

description:
*200th Review!*

Came here with a group of about 5 people. Surprisingly, there was no wait on a Saturday during lunch time. 

The turnip cake is the best I've ever had! A must here! 

The service is pretty good, but these are the pushiest servers I've ever had at a dim sum place. They really want to sell you their food. We sat down and within a minute we had 6 steamers on the table (lol). Oh well, it's better than being ignored! 

Don't get the chicken feet here, doesn't have much flavor and it is bland. 

The shu mai and har gow here are just average, even a bit less than average since they are all stuck together in one piece and when you take them apart they fall apart... 

My second favorite dish besides the turnip cake was the shrimp rice rolls. I would only come back for those two items actually.
author: Leah A.

description:
Dinner at the Imperial is much better than their dim sum in the morning.  Imperial is a neighborhood restaurant and the place definitely in need of a major renovation as it is fairly worn out inside but at least the food is pretty excellent.  

Everything we ordered from the roasted duck to the steamed lobster was very tasty.  The staff was friendly and attentive.  We were there for a birthday celebration and didn't expect the staff will gather around and sang happy birthday with us.  

Imperial has a small parking lot on the side but just not enough to accommodate all the patrons.  Downside is it's very difficult to find parking on the streets so will need lots of patience.

Definitely an alternative for koi.
author: Shirley H.

description: A long existing San Bruno Ave restaurant since the early 90s. The restaurant hasn't changed much since it opened. They still use the same tables and chairs, this restaurant has been here way longer than me. From the best of my knowledge, the original owners were Hoa (Chinese Vietnamese) and they also owned the San Bruno Market down the street. It seems to me that the management did change a few times in the recent years. On with the food, they have the dim sum carts going around the restaurant. The dim sum was okay, the wrappings were not the best, as they broke easily. The steamed custard buns were overcooked and were a little too hard. The food did not very stand out on my opinion, it was more of the Chinatown quality. For better dim sum, I would suggest the restaurants in the Sunset or Richmond. The service here was no good, no refill for tea and the bus boy walked past a few times, but did not clear the empty dishes. The plus about this restaurant is that they have parking, which is rare piece of real estate in San Francisco. There is an parking attendant keeping an eye on the parking lot to prevent break-ins and unauthorized people from using the lot. This restaurant is in a dire need of a renovation, but that means jacking up the prices.
author: Peter C.

description: I came here with the family since it's close to home. They have a little parking lot, which is nice. Another cool part was that you can order your items on the menu, or pick what you want as the waitresses comes around in the carts or trays. It could possibly because I was with my parents who spoke fluent Chinese, so our service was great. The food came by quick and our tea was constantly refilled.
author: Cindy Z.

description:
If you're Chinese, or a self proclaimed expert on dim sum, then you'll know what I mean when I say this is your garden variety dim dum spot. By day, ladies with no facial expression push the carts in a zig zag pattern making sure to hit up all the patrons. By night, the numerous types of fish and crabs sleeping in their glass tanks become someone's dinner. 

After completing a job, my contractor brought me here. We ordered chicken feet, fried taro balls, spare ribs, shrimp, and some other type of dumpling (couldn't understand what that lady was mumbling) It's not much food for 2 grown men, but the grease from everything quickly fills the empty spots in your belly. 

There's nothing really extraordinary about any of the dishes and it's not very memorable, except I got slight food poisoning later in the day. Maye it's just my intolerance for grease, because all of the old school Chinese elders seem to have enjoyed their food. 

**Notes: 

there's a small parking lot next to the restaurant, during busy hours, good luck. there's also some metered street parking. 

drink lots of hot tea to neutralize the oil, iced water can do more damage.

avoid chili oil, that's just like pouring oil over oil
author: James L.

description: The dim sum is fine. Not the worse but there are much better ones if you can drive down the peninsula. The one thing this place needs is face masks for all the servers. I can not get myself to ask for the food that's being spitted on while they walk around asking people if they want their food. Please....it is not costly to stop the spread of germs through their saliva.... Get them all face masks!!!!
author: Mon C.

description:
Thr food was so so the servixe was terrible. I ordered several dishes and somehow all of them had fresh garlic flavor coated. I guess they don't use clean utensils to serve food on the plates. 
I had to remind them the beer and rice I ordered three times. No one asked me how is everything going on.
When I left I didn't tip them because of the mentioner bad service. Then the cashier stopped me and shamed me for not showing gratitude. I explained her that I was not treated well but she said I am obligated to tip them. I wonder if she knows what gratitude means exactly.
author: Yujin S.

description: Great VIP room at the second floor. Totally redone. Nice ambience. The Karaoke set is top of the line with high high high quality sound system. 40 of us went, and we had a blast! Love it!
author: Joz Z.

description:
I walked into this restaurant today to buy pork buns. I found parking across the street ( which is rare.)  Before I went to order, the hostess was extremely rude. When I placed my order, the manager told me, " We no longer make that dish." Now look, if u feel the fact I'm an African-American woman matters in this situation... I humbly agree. In conclusion~ I'm not the review type, but I feel the public should be able to get an honest true experience... so, here's mine.~
                                        God Speed,
                                               Bz
author: Brandy R.

description: Make sure to check your bill. They charged us tea for six kids including the five year old even though the kids don't drink tea! They also charged us an item we didn't ask for nor did we get.
author: Happy L.

description: Here for lunch , there is too much msg in the shrimp dumpling ( har gao)  and chang fun . We also ordered sweet dim sum like egg tart and sa Yung ( sugar donut)  . The custard is rather thick and hard and the pastry is not layered soft . Disappointed :-(
author: V T.

description: Food to go without any folk & napkin, how could we eat. Don't think we eat at home with own utility
author: Vincent W.

description: Great place for a simple and fast dim sum. Not a Koi Palace, but the food is decent and you'll get a seat easily. I like how the place isn't so packed and the TV screens for Sunday football seems to be entertaining.
author: Marlene T.

description: CONTAMINATED FOOD! I got extremely sick from this place for a full week after eating there. Their health score is abysmal. Stupid of me not to check. Go here if you like praying over a porcelain bowl. Awful, awful. Avoid at all costs.
author: Trini L.

description:
Had my wedding here a while ago and didn't find time to yelp, was thinking its s common experience but I found out it's not, and just have to say that the owner is super shady. I'm writing my review now because with the weddings I was involved in after mine, I have discovered no one else to have this issue with their restaurants for their weddings. 

We discussed the wedding details and had an agreement. He said I could pay however I wanted, credit, check, cash etc. I let him know I wanted to pay credit. He asked me to pay half with credit and half with cash to save him on transaction fees. I wanted to use my card to get rebates. Was he going to give me a discount if I paid cash. No, he smiled. 

Anyway, night of the wedding, he comes to ask for payment and refused to take credit as was agreed, so we offered a check. He refused the check and demanded cash. How the hell do you expect anyone to carry 15k+ in cash?! I'm not the mafia. 

So with a shit load of stress my family and I did not need, we had to send someone to make runs to gather cash (and of course they sent one of the servers to come along. Why? I'm not even sure seeing as how most of us were still there)

Long story short, horrible experience, wouldn't do any major events here as they do not keep their word and that's just dishonest. Made promises they didn't keep. 

Occasionally I'll still eat dim sum here because if they refuse my card at least I'll have cash for that or can get it from the atm. 

The food and service were okay, nothing that stood out but honesty is important in business. Some of the staff were really good, some not so much. The owner, not so much
author: Thuy M.

description:
Ok, I hope you all know that tip percentages are calculated on the pre-tax amount. This place has the nerve to print on the receipt the suggested tips at 15%, 18%, and 20% based on the AFTER-tax amount...I don't think it is legal.

We had a few toddlers with us and their tea charge is $1.25 per head regardless if it's a baby. All the kids didn't drink the tea (it's not healthy). They all either had their milk or water bottles. The stupid woman wouldn't adjust the bill.

Some notable items/prices:
$2.99 - small
$4.49 - medium
$5.49 - large

$14.99 - Dried scallop fried rice (not much scallop in it).
$6.49 - rice rolls with beef

The employees pushing the carts around were very nice in general.
author: Taylor L.

description:
If I could give this place under 1 star I would. We went here before going to Cobb's hoping to get good Chinese food. We waited approximately 20 minutes for a server to take our order, never happened. We went to the front desk to ask the host will someone be taking our order and they just shrugged their shoulders, really? Absolutely horrible service and by the way the server never came to our table so we just left without dinner.
If your not of Asian descent don't expect service or acknowledgement. I am sooo disappointed and will never again return to this bias unprofessional establishment.
Horrible!!!!!!
author: Patricia W.

description:
Came here for the first time last Sunday for lunch. The restaurant is pretty big and has high ceilings. But the carpet is filthy and worn out, and it made me kind of not want to eat here. The restaurant did not look clean. 

Service was ok, but some of the people offering the dim sum spoke Cantonese with a very heavy accent so half of the time we could not understand what food they had on their tray/cart.  The food was actually pretty tasty, other than dim sum we got a lamb stew that comes in a mini wok with a burner underneath to keep it boiling.  I usually can't stand lamb, but I tried the soup and veggies, and it was very delicious.  

Street parking was very hard to find.  Women's restroom was weird- the large stall had a carpet laid down inside, right by the toilet.  Can't imagine how dirty that carpet is. I would probably not go back again, especially since the prices weren't that cheap considering the difficulty parking and lack of cleanliness.  I'd rather go to Koi Palace, Grand Palace, or Millbrae.
author: Ellen H.

description:
STAY AWAY FROM THIS PLACE at all cost!

If we didn't take a closer look at the check, we'd had been charged for three items (~$15) that we never ordered nor served to our table. When we brought this issue to their attention, we received no apologies and the staff took those three items off of our bill with an attitude!

And here's another issue... The manager (I believe) let his acquaintance (a.k.a. stranger to us)  to sit down at our table while we still had a bunch of leftover food to box. I was gonna tell the manager how obnoxious his act was, but then I decided not even bother to do that. Instead, I decided to write a review to alert other Yelpers what to expect from this restaurant.
author: Chao G.

description:
AVOID AT ALL COSTS... that is, unless you're craving a serving of HAIR with your meal!

We decided to stop by for a Sunday dim sum fix today. The food was just decent. The wait time for menu orders (not the standard dishes the servers walk around with) was over twenty minutes. 

HAIR NUMBER ONE: When inspecting one of our plates of cha siu bao, a two inch hair was firmly planted on top of a bao. A server was quick to disappear into the kitchen with plate in hand.

HAIR NUMBER TWO: Fast forward to the end of the meal where a second hair was found on top of an order of siu mai (which will be posted into the photo section).

We pointed this dish out to a manager and explained this was the second time a hair was found. He coldly seemed neither surprised nor apologetic.

It makes you wonder how often this happens here or what in the world goes on back there (hair nets anyone?). He simply said he'd remove the plate from the bill and carried the dish to the kitchen.

Unbelievable! For any statistic fans out there our hairy plate ratio was 33%. If 33% of our dishes were blessed with a hair, I wonder what their hairy dish stat is overall at this joint? 

Please do yourself a favor and take your business ANYWHERE else, as it's obvious this place and their management could not care less about their bad hair days.
author: Mike K.

description:
Mediocre at best.

The food is okay. Decent flavor and selection. The price is about normal for what you expect of a dim sum place nowadays. However the food comes to you cold because they have been walking around for so long with it. The jasmine tea is really good, it had a strong jasmine flavor which is hard to find at dim sum restaurants sometimes. There's a $1 service fee per person for tea.

The service is slow. It takes a long time for them to come and take your dishes away. It takes a long time for them to refill your tea. It takes a long time to place your order of kitchen specials. Basically it just takes a long time.

So because they like to move at a snails pace and our family didn't want to wait anymore. We decided to ask for the check, which took another 15 mins to get. We left a tip, and proceeded to the cashier to pay for our meal. She gave us change and my father took the change and returned the empty check book. The cashier immediately scolded us and requested a tip. I think many people forget that a tip is not required. She was so rude about it, which definitely pissed me off.
author: Eva C.

description: This place is straight garbage..... First, my family and I were placed at a table that had a cockroach run across it (first mistake is not leaving the place all together).... Food was average at best.... At the end, my grandparents paid for our food, and our waiter ( who showed attitude and whose body language told us that he didn't to be working today anyways) had the audacity to ask for an even larger tip from them (I was so close to cussing this bum of a waiter out but my savage grandma had beat me to it). Mind you, we literally had to stand up with our hands waving just to get some service... So all in all, don't go to this place unless you're willing to go through the same experience.
author: Darren H.

description:
I will admit that I have an inherent bias for this place, as I live nearby and my family often comes here for any dim sum or dinner gatherings. I do think their food has improved greatly since their previous incarnation, both in dim sum and in their regular entrees. If you come during prime times (weekend mornings, holidays and evenings), you're probably much better off making a reservation first, as this place always seems to be busy. 

The food is more on the pricey side, but most of it is very good. I like getting dim sum here oftentimes, especially the fried changfen (rice roll) platter, which comes with ribs and some greens. Dinner banquet items are also pretty standard, with generous seafood portions. Good times had here all in all.
author: Tony D.

description:
Not my first choice for dim sum, or my second or third actually. The hostess was rude. 

The food is mediocre and very salty. 

Do not recommend.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
Imperial Garden appeared impressive pre-seating/dining. The spaciousness of the venue, grand chandelier, live seafood, and front display of fine brandies fooled me into thinking that I'd be able to recreate one of the fun family dim sum outings of my youth. 

We were seated at a dirty table that was covered up with paper mats (these mats are typical for dim sum restaurants, but we could have been spared the leftover bones from chicken feet). If you're bored during your meal, play a game of "Look What I Found!" under your mats--I guarantee a winner. 

I was hoping for cart-style service too entertain my ideals of the ultimate dim sum experience (see intro), but this place had walk-by staff. The selection is wide and varied and includes all of the dim sum classics. I'd recommend the siu mai which was juicy and well-flavored. The pork buns (both glazed and baked) were below average with very little filling and dry buns. If you come here knowing what you want to eat, you'll be spared the stress of the persistent wait staff--how many times need I reasonably refuse the offer of egg yolk tarts?!

For our party of two, the tab came out to roughly $40... too much for Sunday dim sum.
author: Angel V.

description:
This has become my family's to-go to spots for decent Chinese. Actually, I've been coming here since the early 1990's but things have definitely changed since then. 

Chinese food has always been seen as "cheaper" food, and I totally understand that you can get fried rice or chow mein for pretty cheap. But face it, the price for food has skyrocketed within the past few years that paying ~$12-15 dollar for a dish is quite reasonable. 

With that said, Imperial Garden is not the BEST Chinese but it's quite consistent in preparing dishes. Each time, my family gets a few new items, but we always get the sweet and sour pork chops, the veggies (on choi) and Fujian fried rice. 

We also tried the spicy/sour beef, seafood lettuce wraps, salt and pepper shrimp and fried stuffed tofu. Everything was pretty delicious, but my favorite is the spicy/sour beef. It's a numbing type of spicy, so it may be a new sensation for some of you! It's really good and goes well with right. 

The service is a bit slow, but it's a huge restaurant that seems a bit under-staffed. All in all, give it a shot!
author: Derrick H.

description:
This has to be my favorite Chinese restaurant in SF.  I don't know if it's cause my dad was there to help us with the servers...but in any case, the food was delicious.  

We ordered some sort of fish that was shipped from Hong Kong...ended up being around $150.  I asked the server a couple of times what it was called...but unfortunately, I couldn't make out what he said.  =/  It was definitely good...between the 7 of us, we each got a little portion but it was melt in your mouth yumminess.  

We also ordered geoduck clam made 2 ways...one in a soup...one as a stir fry.  This was also ridiculously good.  We ordered quite a few other dishes such as steamed chicken with ginger and green onion, beef with greens, snow peat sprouts, and a few others.  I thought every single dish was perfect.  At the end, we were given a massive amount of dessert.  There were numerous bowls of grass jelly or mango jello.  We also got the dessert soup and sponge cake.  My favorite was definitely the sponge cake.  It came out steamed, super hot, and soft.  

 Parking is difficult in the area.  Look for a meter and you'll eventually find one.  Great service.  Awesome food.  5 stars.
author: Jen W.

description:
Food was alright. No flavor and very pricey! The service was awful.

They never asked us if we were okay or if we needed anything throughout the entire meal. Then they brought the check before we were even done eating. I thought that was extremely rude. Then I asked for a box and they just tossed the box on the table. 

It's easy to say that I will not be coming back here.
author: Claudia S.

description:
I've come full circle!  I remember I used to frequent this place with my family when I was a young kid living in the Bay Area.  And now I'm eating here as my first dim sum back home in America after being abroad.

The verdict?  Meh... it's aiite.

I do enjoy my fair share of "yum cha" as we Cantonese like to call it, and this place definitely hits the spot.  There are large tables to accommodate any large parties you may bring, although you may need to share a large one when it gets busy during the early morning weekends.

This dim sum place is the typical sit-at-your-table and wait for someone to roll over with the goods for you to pick and choose.  They have their typical dim sum fair- chicken feet with black bean sauce, bbq pork crepes, etc. that will please anyone hungry for it.

My family ends up ordering a ton of dim sum dishes, and usually one or two "specials" that you request the cook to prepare.  We got this fat-ass size Beef chow fun, which was great, but not something my own Dad couldn't make.  Plus, these were a bit on the steep side (Hello... $10?!)

HOWEVER- I will give them props for being the first place I got to play the "let me pay the bill" game with my relatives and ended up treating them to one pricey lunch.

Thank you Imperial Garden Seafood for making me feel like a baller today.

Parking is available in a private lot to the back-right of the restaurant.  There is plenty of street parking on the side if it gets full.
author: Andy N.

description: Great food, terribly slow service, and cockroaches. Lots and lots of cockroaches. Somebody call the Health Department ASAP! I tried posting just half of a star but Yelp doesn't have that capability
author: Atiuh C.

description: This restaurant deserves a ZERO rating, only if Yelp would allow me to do so.  To make my long story short, I ordered a seafood fried rice on a weekday.  When the food arrived at my table, I only saw a plate of fried rice without any seafood on top.  This restaurant is very cheap.  They try to charge you more $$$ for the foods and at the same time, they cut back on the meat portions.  Stay away from this place at all cost !!!!
author: Lisa N.

description: Rarely come to this part of town, their dim sum are very decent. The big plate of black bean steam fun is unique here (see pic), worth trying!
author: CAScuba Y.

description:
Accessibility (Parking / Wait Time)

1/1 Star: there is a small parking lot that I'm never able to get a spot in. Street parking can be hard but is possable at night. No wait to get a table for dinner. 

_____

Service (Waiter / Cleanness / Ambiance)

0/1 Star: bad service. Questionable cleanliness. Nice ambiance but feels warn out/used/aged. 

_____

Taste (0=Not Edible / 1=Edible / 2=Good (average) / 3=Must Try!)

2/3 Stars: food here is good but not amazing. The big clams with glass noodles are good.  I think this place is better for dim sum over dinner. 

_____

Overall Experience

3/5 Stars 

_____

Last Words

The normal kind of bad service from a Chinese restaurant.
author: Elliott N.

description:
The one thing Imperial has got going for it is the location. This is (far as I know) the only place to yum cha in the area. Otherwise, you're going to have to go to the Richmond, Chinatown, or Daly City. I guess a lot of people choose this place for its convenience, because this place was crowded on Sunday morning.

I've been here a couple times during the time I've lived in this neighborhood (read: my life). It's not really the kind of Chinese place my parents like (they usually like smaller establishments rather than the large ones usually used to hold banquets), and they don't really go out for dim sum that much. During the occasions that I've been here, things that I've noticed:

1) Some items are good, others are bad. You probably need to try for yourself what you like and what you don't.

2) The place looks nice at first glance, but it's kind of dingy. I guess it's kind of standard for Chinese restaurants.

3) The waitresses are pushy, returning many many times to try to get you to order what they're holding.

Whenever I come here with my parents, I leave slightly unenthused about the food. However, on the last occasion I came here with the bf's parents. They come here often enough that they've built a rapport with the restaurant managers it seems. They also know which items are good here and which ones aren't (I mean, they turned down the siu mai). I enjoyed the food with them much more than with my parents. So I guess that illustrates what I mean in point #1.

Overall, Imperial is average. I'd come here if I didn't want to venture far for food. Otherwise I'd go somewhere else for better food/experience.
author: Denise C.

description:
Over the years, I've watched this place be empty, suddenly find customers, and be empty again. Right now (mid-end 2013), it's got customers. Seems kinda sketchy when that happens.

I've heard the place is a cooperative now, with all the workers contributing money to keep the place afloat. The space is good, parking to the side so you don't have to search. 

Food...I don't see much of a difference. It's standard dim sum, nothing amazing about it. Perhaps its because now the food is at a reasonable cost? Before, they'd be shelling out dim sum that looks pre-frozen and charging you as though you went out to Koi Palace or something ridiculous. 

Service is pretty good here. The staff here are pretty attentive. Though...if you ask for a small dish for the Worcestershire sauce, the women passing out Dim Sum will find you a small place. Nuances.
author: Lily W.

description: I am really happy and satisfy by the customer service and quality of food that this restaurant provides to me. I love to eat lobster noodle, pork bun and steam mushroom bread. Quite enjoy to dine here. This review is 100% from my pure heart, no personal contact with anyone or benefits gain from this company.
author: Olive C.

description: Tired of waiting hours for a table at an SF Chinatown dim sum place on the weekend. Have I discovered the answer for you! This great dim sum/Cantonese seafood palace is located in Visitacion Valley in the SW corner of the intersection of 101/280, just within the city limits. Food is excellent and the dim sum is served by push cart/trolley. What a throwback! All of the favorites are present including my fav - chicken feet! Plus plenty on street parking. Discover this new satellite Chinese commercial neighborhood located on San Bruno Avenue. But keep it a secret. (Last time we went, my wife and were the only non-Chinese eating there. No better recommendation than that.)
author: Steve G.

description: Food is very authentic, service is good. I like the 茶皇鸡 and 乳鸽。My daughter lives thr walnut prawn.
author: jack o.

description: Warning Warning.  Scam alert. They dont put dim sum prices on the menu.  Dim sum are super expensive and you will find that when u get your bill.  Ask waiter how much dim sum is, if they wont tell u, just leave.
author: Ann R.

description:
So most of the reviews here is for dimsum, but let me tell you about dinner. I can see why this place gets doesn't get too many stars. Sometimes their servers are pushy on trying to get you to order the largest lobster and the most expensive dishes, and sometimes the plate or cups are kinda dirty, but the food is actually pretty good. I think the food has improved a lot in the past few years. Let me tell you about some memorable dishes.

Peking Duck : probably the best dish I had here for dinner. The skin was cut so thinly and most of the fat was removed, but it still had its crunchy texture. The white buns were soft and came with hoisin sauce. Very good! The meat of the duck was made into another dish where we ate it in lettuce wraps! I suggest you order this because it's nice having duck in 2 dishes.

Honey Walnut Prawns - good! Nothing outstanding, but it's just like the classic walnut prawns you normally get at chinese restaurants

Lobster Yee Mien - We got like a 5 pound lobster. They even took the live lobster out to show us, which totally freaked my mom out and she yelled at them to take it back in. How would I know if they didn't switch up the live lobster with some frozen lobster in the kitchen? Haha but thats okay. This dish was still good! Super large portions for family style.

A bit on the expensive side, but not a bad chinese dinner.
author: Carmen C.

description:
My dad calls me Friday afternoon (convo translated from chinese) --
dad:  are you coming home tomorrow?
me:  no, why?
dad:   it's your grandpa's 80th birthday -- we're having a big banquet.  [his bday isn't actually for another 2 months, but they're celebrating early]
me:  i already have plans tomorrow morning, so i'm not going to have enough time to drive back [from san diego to san francisco]... i would have to book a flight.
dad:  well, go book a flight then.
me:  you could have told me sooner, it would have saved me a lot of money.
dad:  well, i didn't think it'd be important for you to come before, but everyone's going to be there so it'll look bad if you don't show up.  

turns out, my grandpa's favorite grandchild didn't show up because she was going to prom.  i'm his least favorite.  FML.

*****ANYWAY, the real review starts here:

Came here for my grandpa's 80th birthday -- we took over half the restaurant that Saturday night, but it was actually pretty empty anyway.  The food was pretty standard, nothing to rave about, but definitely not bad.  We've actually been here for dim sum many times since my grandparents live nearby, and again, nothing to rave about.  But, the staff is pretty friendly and accommodating.  I have no idea what the normal prices are here since I don't ever pay for the meals, but the banquet cost a little over $4,000 for ~120 people.
author: Anna C.

description:
As soon as I walked up to this place I see huge pictures of skinned animals, such as an iguana being displayed in the window. Not exactly the type of thing to wet my appetite. In fact, it did the complete opposite. 

We were immediately greeted by a few very welcoming and friendly staff as we walked in the door, so I had to let go of the fried iguana in the front, because how could I be nasty or rude to these very genuinely, nice people? We then took a walk back to all the live seafood in all of the tanks at the back of the restaurant-- and my stomach started churning. Most of the fish were stacked,and packed tightly in each tank-- even the Dungeness Crab (the biggest ones I've ever seen in my life) had no room to move in their tank. They were all on their deathbed, in very tight quarters and it was really hard for me to get over it... My friend on the other hand, was eyeing all the tanks, each fish and crab one by one, like a hungry tiger, salivating over it's prey, it's about to feast on. It's crazy, I think he was actually drooling when his eyes made contact with the Dungeness Crab... 

How could I not enjoy someone getting so much pleasure out of this place? So I lightened up and tried a few things on the menu-- in which Uncle Bill, our server suggested. 

We had some sauteed mustard greens with garlic, snow peas with black mushrooms, and yes-- some of their fried cod. The fried cod came with jalepenos, peppers and cabbage; I must say it was delicious (and I don't think it came from the tank, I hope..) The veggies were fresh and not too greasy or over-cooked. We even had some delicious dessert made from Tapoioca and black beans (don't ask me what it's called, Uncle Bill just brought it out.) 

The interior looks like a very- old school, mom n pop Chinese restaurant and the staff here provided us with a nice, personalized type of service. Not sure I would run back here or make a special trip to dine here, but it's an okay place.
author: Cassandra E.

description:
I'm excited to have a Dim Sum place a block away from my work since it's convenient for our 45-minute lunch break. The place is ALWAYS packed full, but they manage to seat us right away and we're easily in and out in 30 minutes or less.

My first visit we were starving and chose about 6 dim sum dishes - we were shocked to see a bill of $37!!! For dim sum?!?! Apparently one of the pork dishes we got was $14.99. I'm still not convinced that we weren't just ripped off b/c we're not asian. The dish was not even served hot.

None the less, we went back again and were careful of what we ordered. The sui mai is good and flavorful, the scallop 'roll' is really more like shrimp. Everything is about average quality, but having lived in the Richmond for many years, I know there is a LOT better dim sum out there. Second time around bill was more reasonable, but we were disappointed to see we were charged $2 for our tea. Really?!
author: Rachel G.

description: Looks like the management allowed people to smoke inside which is not acceptable ! Do not feel like going back to this place
author: Nikhila M.

description: Came here for a wedding and the food was decent. I never had dim sum here but I'll give it a try one day. The only thing I didn't like was the unsanitary bathroom so minus a star... why is it that during weddings they don't help keep it clean? Well, other than that their food service was good and waving the waiters down for ice was quick and on the dot. The new remodel is pretty nice for a wedding.
author: Helen N.

description: I had a very bad experience eating at this restaurant. I ordered a wonton udon soup at dimsum time.  The udon and the soup weren't  taste right, it was like overnight spoiled food taste.  I talked to the manager, his attitude and answer were so unprofessional. Of cause, I didn't eat that soup. I left them 1 dollar tip. I would never go back to that restaurant again!
author: LQ T.

description: worst service ever!!!! do not come here!! zero stars if that was an option.
author: Sophia L.

description: Good food absolutely.  We went with friends that are regulars they definitely know what to order. Delicious desserts.
author: Tina B.

description: Both my husband and I plus heard many of my coworker's friends' credit cards got fraudulent charges after being used by this restaurant. Someone at this restaurant is stealing credit card info and giving it to someone to make fraudulent purchases. Either their machine is rigged or something. When we mentioned it to them, we were brushed off instead of trying to look into it.
author: London M.

description: Very bad service!!!!!! No matter take the order or check out they both need a long time!!!!! Even though there was only few customers!!!!!!!
author: Aviva C.

description: Just don't go this restaurant . the food taste so terrible . And overpricing ! The parking is terrible too !
author: Jessie H.

description: WORST EXPERIENCE OF MY LIFE! First off I'm currently on crutches and 20 days into my recovery from surgery, they were not accommodating for me at all. Then they were barely acknowledging my friend and I since we were the only 2 people there who were not Asian, talking shit as they left the table when we declined a dish like chicken feet. The thing that was extremely unbelievable was they charged us $2.80 for 2 waters, mind you it was not like sparkling water it was tap water!!! Then when we asked why we were charged for wTer she couldn't give us a reason! Like it just felt as though they didn't want to bother with us! It was my best friends first time to dim sum and I had never been to this place mistakingly not looking at the reviews but that jug made her experience that much worse! We only got 2 dishes and after that plus the 2 waters they charged us for it was $17 and not even good!! WILL NEVER EVER GO HERE AGAIN OR RECOMMEND THIS PLACE!!
author: Sierra S.

description:
We notice the "Grand Opening" sign as we were driving down the street. Knowing how Chinese restaurants will keep those signs up until they fall down on their own, we walked in with an open mind. The restaurant front looked like it had been recently remodeled and there were numerous congratulatory plants just inside the entrance that didn't appear to be super dusty. 

There were a few people waiting so we dutifully got a number and waited to be called. We were told to expect about a 10 minute wait and they were spot on. We were seated at a table against the front window and our tea order taken. Because the table was being set-up when we arrived, they had to bring us plates, napkins and chopsticks. 

As the food runners went by, we selected several dishes. Being hungry, we were on the fourth dish before I realized that our tea had not yet arrived. Flagging down an employee in a suit, he apologized and brought the tea immediately and filled our cups before leaving the pot.

The selection of dim sum was reasonably decent however we were disappointed that some of the "standard" dishes were not presented before we were done eating. We never saw chicken feet, ha gow, or stuffed bell peppers. What we did have was:

Roast Suckling Pig (4) - perfect crispy skin, lean meat, flavorful

Seaweed Salad/Jellyfish (1) - the jellyfish had what i thought was an odd flavor. enough so that it also ruined the seaweed salad for me. my dining companion thought that it was just different from what i was used to and finished the dish so i didn't send it back.

Scallop & Shrimp Gow (1) - it was sold as scallop gow. the wrapper was very thick and the scallop had been chopped up and mixed with shrimp. 

Lotus Leaf Rice (4) - very flavorful; had all the right ingredients

Hom Sui Gok (4) - good flavor; decent filling

Pork Sui Mai (4) - nice and fat

The last four dishes were served piping hot. The server even warned us to be careful of the Hom Sui Gok as it had just come out of the fryer.

I wouldn't go out of my way to visit this restaurant again but if I were in the area, I wouldn't hesistate to go again either.
author: Dexter D.

description:
When this place reopened, I was quick on my feet to grab a seat here. Things have changed after all those years closed, mostly the food and prices. Coming here on a weekend is a bad idea if you've ever read Anthony Bourdain's Kitchen Confidential. Do yourself a favor and come during the weekdays instead of waiting nearly half an hour for a table.

Among the food changes is the classic Pan Fried Noodle. The noodle are split in the middle as you can see in the various pictures on this page and the goodies are inside. I'm not a big fan of this dish because I don't like the fried noodles on the top and side to begin with, but my dad is crazy for this dish because of the presentation is unique. I was always a fan of the saucy noodles in the bottom. Give me a plate of that and I'll be a happy yelper.

Everything else is pretty standard. Nothing really stood out and for the price, I was really hoping something would surprise me. I'll probably only come back if my family feels like coming here and not to the Sunset for dim sum.
author: George Z.

description:
Food was pretty good, wide selection and good taste.
Best Dim Sum place in the San BRuno and around area.
Plus there is parking so it makes it ideal if you want Dim Sum and don't want to travel all the way to Chinatown or Richmond.
Service was good and Wait time was not too bad for a weekend!
Overall good experience!

Try at least one of their dessert items, tofu fa with ginger sweet sauce, mango jello, or almond coconut jello!!!
author: Nicholas C.

description: Had the most horrible experience at a dim sum restaurant ever. We had to wait over an hour for a table and when we finally got a table upstairs, the area smelled like pee. We were given a different table after we had walked out the restaurant. Service was horrible: they didn't even set our table for us, we had to do that ourselves.  And when we had the dim sum, everything was lukewarm or didn't taste right. I am never coming back here again and highly advise people to avoid this place like the plague. I hope the food inspector comes by and shuts this restaurant down.
author: Kristen C.

description:
I have been here several times only for lunch (Dim Sum) the manager is a great guy the service is great maybe to good LOL they come to your table constantly kind of hard to have a conversation. Having said that I would rather they come to my table then have to flag them down.

The food is great never had a bad experience. I will caution you to watch your ticket that they stamp, I've had to have them adjust my bill a couple of times.
author: Charlie G.

description:
"A fish, dishonest waiter, and an innocent family walk into a bar..." Except that it's a restaurant. And so the tale of the ridiculous restaurant begins. 

Huge ripoff. So much for helping out the neighborhood businesses. 

I came on a semi-windy night with my family. There were only a few other groups eating there -- I'd say no more than 5. We were a group of six. The waiter starts chatting up my mother and aunt, and recommended a fish since, hey, we're in a sort of fishy mood. (It should have been a clear indicator at this point that something FISHY was about to occur at the end of the meal.)

Before I launch into full restaurant bashing mode, I will preface my bashing with some background. Our family is Chinese, we've been to a ton of Chinese restaurants all over the city. Usually, when we ask a waiter to recommend a fish, we take the recommendation -- with the norm being that the fish is approximately between $40 to $60 dollars. We don't look at the menu to confirm price because hey, that's THE NORM. 

So our food comes, and it seems that fish is the motif for 3 out of 5 dishes we have. There's fish soup, fish with vegetables, and fried fish coated with sauce. Okay, so it seems like the fish was big enough to make three large dishes out of. No biggie. The fried stuff was a little salty, and all the dishes were pretty greasy. 

Yet.

The bill comes, and the FISH alone is $149. Our TOTAL bill was about $180. 

For six people. (FYI, we're six women, not huge guys who eat a TON.) At some mediocre Chinese restaurant. 

Gee, thanks for telling us the fish you recommended we order was MORE THAN HALF THE BILL. Who the freak recommends a $149 fish for a party of six? Okay, so we didn't look at the menu to check, BUT, they do NOT do this at other Chinese restaurants. 

Totally dishonest pricks who will never receive our business again.
author: Betty T.

description:
Better than I expected for San Bruno Avenue.  

OK, I am not that familiar with the Portola district.  It seems, as a decorator or landscaper might say, to have no theme.  But there are plenty of Chinese and Mexican restaurants on San Bruno, and the Imperial Garden seems to stand out.  

Three of us showed up for dinner around 5:30 pm on Sunday.  The waiter was friendly and helpful.  The menus had pictures of everything.  Everything!  This made large plastic menus, but we were able to browse the food without wondering what it was.  Many delicious looking items had descriptions that took me aback:  pig stomach, alligator belly bone in, braised sea cucumber, whole pig, whole goat, whole rabbit, roasted or fried squab, etc.  I'm sure it's great eating for a Chinese connoisseur, but for our first visit I wanted to stick with things I knew so I could get a baseline impression.  

The prices looked a little high, until we saw the size of the dishes.  It would have been perfectly satisfying to stick to one dish per person, but we succumbed to temptation and ordered 4 dishes for 3 people.  

The won ton soup was not nearly as salty as the soups we've had at other restaurants, and that is a good thing.  The chicken broth in it was excellent.  

The broccoli beef was a little fatty, but they compensated for that by steaming the broccoli instead of soaking it in the beef fat.  Another plus.  

We also had a mixed seafood plate, with shrimp the size of my fingers and scallops all over the plate, and the tastiest peas I've had in years.  

We bound all of this together with shrimp fried rice, which had more of the large shrimp, and also a lot of squid tube slices, along with the usual egg and diced pork.  

We all agreed to stick with the black tea for our beverage, as tea has the amazing property of cutting fat.  Fortunately, there was not a great need for this property in this meal.  

The three of us ate more than we should have, with more food left over when we were too stuffed to eat any more, for about $60 + tip.  The scales tell me I gained 4 pounds yesterday.  

This restaurant is huge.  The dining room goes on forever, with 8-tops and lazy susans stretching to infinity.  It was a little odd to see an open garbage can in the dining room near the back, and a small open office near the front.  I've seen the office in other Chinese restaurant layouts before, though.  The room was spacious, a high ceiling that had a neon-lit dome in the center, and a giant phoenix and dragon mural along one wall.  There were other dining rooms off the main room, as well as, it appears, upstairs.  The men's room was clean, and it had flowers on the wash basin counter.  

Another plus:  by the time we left at 7:30 pm, the room was full.  Almost everyone there was Chinese.  That's a good testimonial.
author: David D.

description:
The parking in the area is bad. Bunch of people with nothing to do but hang around the narrow streets outside. The place smells funky at times from food that wasn't cleaned up and the tanks of water in the back. 

The food is loaded with MSG, had to drink a gallon of water after having Dim Sum here. The people who work here treat customers like they are at McDonald.
author: M C.

description:
This place is called the NEW Imperial Garden now and it's definitely much better. They switched owners, food is much better and service is also better. You'll believe me once you see there's actually LINES outside this place now!

They always have the lobster noodle on special for like, $15??? it's a steal!

Try it. It's not the same as the old sucky Imperial Garden
author: Sandra L.

description: BE VERY CAREFUL COMING TO THIS PLACE. I'd give it no stars if I could. My family of 17 people came here last night for mid autumn Chinese holiday. The food was very mediocre. We ordered off the menu and in the end the bill was extremely high. They had overcharged us by a lot. We asked them why and they said "these are our holiday prices" which is not written anywhere on the menu or when we were ordering. It explains why a place like this was not busy at all on a Chinese holiday. They gave us dessert which was grass jelly that was completely bitter. When was asked for syrup the rude waiter said "why do you need so much sweet?" Umm you're dessert is completely bitter. To top it off, when I went to the restroom the stall door was so rusty I got stuck in there. This place is not worth your money or time. The sad thing is we came here for dim sum earlier that same day...and to get ripped off coming back for dinner is just ridiculous. I will never come back to this place. It is terrible, dirty, and disgusting. I am so disappointed.
author: Jane S.

description:
This is going to be a simple review as I didn't pay for the meal and I don't want to list all of the dim sum items we ordered. 

Dimsum: not as fresh as other dim sum places we went to. Some of the steamed dimsum stuff was lukewarm to close to cold. I was so disappointed. 

I would avoid the Taro bun at all costs! Not worth it here. I am shocked to say that one of my fave dishes here was the pork blood. It was warm and full of flavor. 

Singapore Noodles: Bland, but at least it was freshly cooked and piping hot! I was ok with just adding hot sauce. I also ended up using the sauce from the pork blood dish we ordered. It helped with adding some flavor to this dish. 

Lobster Noodle: Bland. What is up with all their dishes being so bland? I just don't get it. 

Overall, service was good. Tea was filled up often and we got to pick a table we wanted to sit at (bf's family knows the head server). The dimsum just isn't good here.
author: Erica T.

description:
I've lived in the area for 25 years and drove by this restaurant thousands of times and never really paid any attention to it. I've only noticed that there was a crazy amount of people waiting inside and outside. I honestly thought that those people were there for a smoke break or something. I should have known better. It's an Asian restaurant that serves dim sum with tons of Asians outside waiting in anticipation to get in. This can only mean one thing. The food there must be good. DUH!

My friend and I went on a random Sunday during non-peak hours. We're from San Francisco, so we were higher than a kite. Don't act surprised. We haven't eaten all day and our eyes were definitely bigger than our stomachs. But, LET. ME. TELL. YOU. The food was good to our surprise! The dim sum wasn't oily or soggy at all. The service was good, not the best, but good. I could tell our waiter was getting annoyed whenever we would ask for something. You can also tell if they have good service when your glass of water is NEVER empty. In my case, it was always empty. I was parched and I love water, what can I say?

I do recommend coming here to eat. It's simple and good.
author: Abby A.

description:
The stars kid you not.  This place is hardly mediocre for it's cost.

I went here for dim sum the other morning and well, I wasn't too impressed.  The chicken feet were served COLD.  Or, it was hot in some areas, then cold in another? It's just disappointing when food isn't served hot/warm the way it should be.  The "ha cheurn" (shrimp wrap thing, sorry IDK how to really translate this lololol) had stale which was even more disappointing! I mean, I can go on forever but there's no reason to because I'm sure others have said it all. 

But I really wanted to point out the service here.  Or the manager in charge.. He was NOT friendly AT ALL.  Like, when my mom asked for boxes, he didn't even say anything, just gave this mean-looking stare and walked off -- I honestly though he just ignored my mom.  I don't know man, only reason I came was because we were in a rush because I had work at my family was visiting.  Maybe if I do come again, it will be a long time and hopefully service will be better then.
author: Lisa L.

description:
Food is unfresh. Fish are floating with bottoms up in the tank, yet the waiters are convincing us they were fresh.

Frog is clearly not fresh, and $14 for one frozen frog is a bit pricy. 

The baby "lamb" does not taste like lamb and is a bit small to believe that it could be a lamb. 

For someone craving Chinese food, this serves to be a great disappointment to my standards.
author: Joseph T.

description:
first thoughts: not a lot of people here. kinda empty.
first dish/dim sum: chicken fingers. a lot of grease. oily.
tea is kinda watered down. would rather have milk tea by this point.
portions are small. second dish: still kinda watery and greasy.
food come got at first, now not so much.
good service. food came at a fast pace provided for the number of people. hate to see when it gets busy. food is alright. same trend. bland and greasy. its ok for the only dim sum restaurant in the area.
author: Anderson H.

description:
Came here before I saw all the subpar reviews, and I must say that they are probably right, *BUT* those reviews are now outdated. Even my cousin said they were here a few months ago for dim sum, and thought the food was overall bad.

We came here for dim um in late August, and again today (9/23). The food is fantastic! In talking to one of their managers, we learned that ownership has changed, and they changed the chef for dim sum very recently. I saw specifically about the Taro Bun being disgusting a few days after eating there, but we also had that bun and thought it was quite tasty.  The below are the items we have ordered over the course of the last two visits, and are my recommendations:

Deep Fried Meat Dumplings
Deep Fried Sesame Balls
Baked BBQ Pork Buns
Taro Buns
Chicken Feet w/Bean Sauce
Steamed Shrimp Dumplings
Steamed Rice Noodles (Beef)
Crispy Steamed Rice Noodle
Fried Tofu Skin w/Shrimp & Chives
Salt & Pepper Squid
Lobster Lo Mein
San Francisco Fried Rice

There were a couple items that we tried and thought were meh. These were the beef trip, the steamed rice noodle (shrimp), the lotus leaf wrapped sticky rice, and the Shanghai dumpling. Very meh.

The restaurant is generally clean, but the do need to do something about those fugly cardboard leading to the bathroom, and inside the bathroom. In talking to the restaurant manager (today), I referenced Yelp and their bad reviews. I spoke specifically about the cardboard, and that bathroom needs to be cleaner. He talked about the carpet, then said that they have not generated enough revenue to change things like the old carpet. It's a bad situation - they have a bad reputation, but their food has improved from those reviews (dim sum only - dunno about dinner).

On a Sunday around noon, this place was fairly full. I recommend it. The food is delicious, and the service was decent. They seem to be in the middle of a full reboot, and I believe they'll get there if everyone will give them another chance. For dim sum, you won't regret it.
author: Bor C.

description:
After reading some reviews on this place, I expected the food to be alright. The food wasn't the greatest, but it wasn't the worst. I ordered the walnut shrimp, salt & pepper porkchops, and preserved fish fried rice. The shrimp had too much of the sauce which made me pretty full after a couple of shrimp. The fried rice wasn't the greatest; I've had better in San Jose (Home). The porkchops were actually my favorite. They're really crispy and tender while hot, so eat them quick! 

The place is somewhat dirty & could use some repainting. 

I will probably come back here soon considering how close it is to my aunt's house, but won't really come for the food.
author: Nam N.

description: The food was okay, but the portions were ridiculously small and expensive.  The end.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
Heard ownership changed and we had dinner with our friends here. It was nearly full.

Overall food was good, not bad nor great.

1st impression, Hostesses were dressed in casual everyday clothing, so you wouldn't know they worked there except they greeted/seated you.

Service was OK, food came out fairly quickly. Tea pot was never refilled....one waiter originates from the former Hing Lung on  Boardway St (which will explain "type of service").

We got very basic dishes:

BBQ pork/Roast Duck appetizer - pork was on the lean side while duck was juicy!

Sweet/Sour Pork -  batter/sauce was a bit weird - can't put my finger on it, but it wasn't the flavor I'm accustomed to.

Beef and Brocolli - not oily and lots of brocolli

Seafood chow mien - had shrimp, squid and scallops. The squid was really good.

Ying/Yang rice - pretty good as well!

Average price per dish was $14.88 

Dinner came with free red bean soup  for dessert. 

Bathroom was OK - they used cardboard under the men's urinals.
author: Peter L.

description:
This place was so disgusting i dont even know where to start.. came here day after Christmas for dim sum with my family. It was super packed and we waited for maybe about 15 minutes for a table (not bad). We got seated on the "2nd floor" which really looks like an add-on space. It was super stuffy up there and with poor ventilation. The tables were dirty and the plates felt super sticky. 

The food isn't even half decent. i took 2 bites and was already "full"

will not return for the life of me...
author: Jenny G.

description: So bad. We made a reservation and booked the table but we had to wait 30 min to get a new table because they screwed up our reservation. The servers will bump into you without saying excuse me or sorry.
author: Vivian H.

description:
I would not recommend this restaurant to anyone :(
1. Over price chinese food
2. No customer services
3. Half an hour to wait for my food
4. Missing ingredient on fired rice :( & said that's how they do it ???
5. This place is kind of run down!!
author: Charlie H.

description:
